results.headline: Despair and Poetry at Margins of Society

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Exiles

results.summary_short: “The Exiles” is a beautifully photographed slice of down-and-almost-out life, a near-heavenly vision of a near-hell.

results.headline: The Life of a World-Class Sex Kitten

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eight Miles High

results.summary_short: The mythologizing of the ’60s gets a lusty, Germanic twist in “Eight Miles High.”

results.headline: Magic Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Death Defying Acts

results.summary_short: “Death Defying Acts,” a fictionalized love story involving Harry Houdini, could be a sweet little discovery if only the relationship at the core of it were more convincing.

results.headline: Six Flags Subterranean Style, or Something Like It
results.display_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Journey to the Center of the Earth

results.summary_short: If “Journey to the Center of the Earth” is not a ride, then what is it? One thing it may not be, quite, is a movie.

results.headline: Like Bogey, but With a Really Big Fist

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hellboy II: The Golden Army

results.summary_short: There are moments in “Hellboy 2: The Golden Army” capable of delighting even the most jaded, comic-book-weary summer-blockbuster conscript.

results.headline: Old Boy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Harold

results.summary_short: “Harold” is the type of one-note dead zone ideally suited for a bathroom break while sitting home on a Saturday night, alone and semidrunk, in front of the television.

results.headline: An Itty-Bitty Brother From Another Planet

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Meet Dave

results.summary_short: “Meet Dave,” the latest in a long line of disposable Eddie Murphy vehicles, plays like a half-hour sitcom episode that has been stretched to feature-length running time.

results.headline: A Web of Cynicism

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of August

results.summary_short: Embracing superficiality in both subject and style, “August” is a low-key drama in high-tech clothing.

results.headline: Feeding a Creative Headwater

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La Riviere Gentille

results.summary_short: “La Rivière Gentille” affords an exceedingly long afternoon in the company of the artist Louise Bourgeois.

results.headline: Soldiers on the Ground in California, Facing All the Conflicts of Iraqi Towns

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Full Battle Rattle

results.summary_short: This documentary gives a remarkably thorough and detailed account of the difficult conditions facing American soldiers in Iraq.

results.headline: Land of the Meek, and Home of the Deeply Blue

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kabluey

results.summary_short: “Kabluey” is a bittersweet indie comedy whose hapless protagonist spends a good part of the movie waddling along the side of a highway in a blue foam-rubber suit.

results.headline: Beyond Fear and Loathing
results.display_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Dr. Hunter S. Thompson

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gonzo: The Life and Work of Dr. Hunter S. Thompson

results.summary_short: “Gonzo” is a fascinating history lesson and a bit of a cautionary tale about how fame can turn into the scourge of talent.

results.headline: Children Without Childhoods

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Very Young Girls

results.summary_short: Notwithstanding the coyly suggestive title, “Very Young Girls” is very far from exploitative.

results.headline: Desperately Seeking Sex and Identity, With Snark

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Holding Trevor

results.summary_short: “Holding Trevor,” a portrait of 20-something gay men and their straight friends, is a joyless exploration of middle-class deadbeats.

results.headline: The Gifts That Song Can Bring
results.display_title: We Are Together: The Children of Agape Choir

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Are Together: The Children of Agape Choir

results.summary_short: “We Are Together” is another feel-good documentary about a feel-bad topic: the bright-eyed, golden-voiced children of Agape, an orphanage in South Africa.

results.headline: A Tale of Two Minds, Spinning Out of Control

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Diminished Capacity

results.summary_short: “Diminished Capacity” touches earnestly on heart-heavy issues of loss: loss of memory, of love and, perhaps because of the local angle, of (or rather by) the Chicago Cubs.

results.headline: Summer of ’94, With Boy, Girl, Love and Dope Sales

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wackness

results.summary_short: “The Wackness” makes a good-faith effort to steer clear of coming-of-age story clichés, and succeeds and fails in roughly equal measure.

results.headline: Snared in a Dark Labyrinth When His Wife Disappears

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tell No One

results.summary_short: Guillaume Canet’s delicious contemporary thriller “Tell No One” is “Vertigo” meets “The Fugitive” by way of “The Big Sleep.” That is meant as high praise.

results.headline: Able to Leap Tall Buildings, Even if Hung Over

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hancock

results.summary_short: “Hancock” makes for one unexpectedly satisfying and kinky addition to Hollywood’s superhero chronicles.

results.headline: An Angel Rides in to Preserve a Family (and India)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Thoda Pyaar Thoda Magic

results.summary_short: “Thoda Pyaar, Thoda Magic” (“A Little Love, a Little Magic”) has a buoyancy and optimism that trump the predictability of its story.
